columns.text:
In this exercise, we are trying to raise money for our company, and we have two types of bonds at our disposal - a regular coupon bond and a zero-coupon bond.

We'll analyze these two types of bonds and compare them.

Let's get started!

Let's start by explaining the key terms of this exercise. A bond that pays out no coupons is called a zero-coupon bond. As a result, zero-coupon bonds typically trade at a discount, meaning investors make money when they redeem them for face value at maturity. Despite not paying out any interest, a zero-coupon bond issuer deducts interest from its taxes every year. In the same way, the owner must pay taxes on interest accrued every year, even though the owner does not receive any interest. The IRS amortization method is the method currently proposed by the tax laws. The rule says that we determine the implicit interest by amortizing the loan. To do this, we should calculate the bond price change for each year. The difference in the bond's price for the year represents the interest on which we need to pay taxes.

**Part a.)** In this part of the exercise, we will calculate the number of bonds needed to raise the required capital. The exercise text states that: 1. We have to raise $53 million. 2. The period to maturity is 20 years. Given that the bonds are semiannual, the number of compounding periods will be 40 (20 times 2) 3. The annual yield to maturity is 6%. Thus, the semiannual yield to maturity is 3%.

Recall the general equation to calculate the bond price:

$$\text{Bond Price} = C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t}$$

Where:

FV - Face value

C - Coupon payment

t - The number of compounding periods

YTM - Yield to maturity

By inputting the given values into the Eq.$(1)$, we get the following bond price for the coupon bond:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price}_\text{ CouponBond} &= C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] 
&= (\$1,000 \times 2.65\%) \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 2.65\%)^{40}}}{2.65\%}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 2.65\%)^{40}} \\[15pt] 
&= \$648.72936 + \$351.27063 \\[15pt] 
&= \$1,000
\end{aligned}$$

Now, to get the needed number of bonds , we can divide the amount we need to raise ($47 million) by the bond price: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Number of bonds} &= \frac{\text{Amount needed}}{\text{Bond price}} \\[15pt] &= \frac{\$53,000,000}{\$1,000} \\[15pt] &= 53,000 \end{aligned}$$

In the case of a zero-coupon bond, there are no coupon payments. 

Hence, the first part of Eq.$(1)$ is equal to zero. By inputting the rest of the given values, we get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Bond Price}_\text{ Zero Bond} &= C \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ YTM)^t}}{YTM}\Bigg) + \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^t} \\[15pt] 
&= 0 \times \Bigg(\dfrac{1 - \frac{1}{(1+ 0.03)^{40}}}{0.03}\Bigg) + \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 0.03)^{40}} \\[15pt] 
&= 0 + \$351.27063 \\[15pt] 
&= \$351.27063
\end{aligned}$$

Now, to get the needed number of zero-coupon bonds, we divide the amount we need to raise ($47 million) by the bond price: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Number of bonds} &= \frac{\text{Required Amount}}{\text{Bond price}} \\[15pt] &= \frac{\$53,000,000}{\$351.27063} \\[15pt] &= 150,881 \end{aligned}$$

**Part b.)** In this part, we need to calculate the company's repayment in twenty years for each type of bond. In the case of a coupon bond, we'll calculate the repayment using the below equation: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Repayment}_\text{Coupon Bond} = \text{RA} + \text{RA}\times\text{CR} \tag{2} \end{aligned}$$ Where: RA - Required amount (in our case, it is $53 million) CR - Coupon Rate (3%)

By inputting the values into Eq.$(2)$, we get the following repayment on the coupon bonds: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Repayment}_\text{Coupon Bond} &= \text{RA} + \text{RA}\times\text{CR} \\[10pt] &= \$53,000,000 + \$53,000,000 \times 2.65\% \\[10pt] &= \$54,404,500 \end{aligned}$$

In the case of a zero-coupon bond, we calculate the repayment by multiplying the face value of the bonds by the total number of bonds issued: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Repayment}_\text{Zero Bond} = \text{FV}\times\text{NOIB} \tag{3} \end{aligned}$$ Where: FV - Face value NOIB - Number of issued bonds

By inputting the values into Eq.$(3)$, we get the following repayment on the zero-coupon bonds: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Repayment}_\text{Zero Bond} &= \text{FV}\times\text{NOIB} \\[10pt] &= \$1,000 \times 150,881 \\[10pt] &= \$150,881,000 \end{aligned}$$

**Part c.)** In this part, we'll compute the first-year after tax cash flows for both types of bonds and compare them. $$\begin{aligned} \text{Aftertax Cash Flow}&= \text{CFBT}\times(1 - \text{TR}) \tag{4} \end{aligned}$$ Where: CFBT - Cash Flow Before Tax TR - Tax Rate

For coupon bonds, the cash flow before tax for the first year is equal to the interest for that year: $$\begin{aligned} \text{CFBT}_ \text{Coupon Bond} &= \$53,000,000 \times 5.3\% \\[10pt] &= \$2,809,000 \end{aligned}$$ We can now input the above value along with the tax rate of 35% (it is specified in the exercise text) and calculate the aftertax cash flow : $$\begin{aligned} \text{Aftertax Cash Flow}_ \text{Coupon Bond}&= \$2,809,000 \times(1 - 35\%) \\[10pt] &= \$1,825,850 \end{aligned}$$

For zero-coupon bonds, the cash flow before tax for the first year equals the total interest deduction for that year. We assume the IRS amortization rule - the total interest deduction is equal to the difference in a bond's price between the start and the end of the year, multiplied by the number of issued bonds. Hence, the cash flow before tax is: $$\begin{aligned} \text{CFBT}_ \text{Zero Bond} &= \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^{40}} - \frac{FV}{(1+ YTM)^{38}} \times \text{NOIB}\\[15pt] &= \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 2.65\%)^{40}} - \frac{\$1,000}{(1+ 2.65\%)^{38}} \times 150,881\\[15pt] &= \$18.86402 \times 150,881 \\[15pt] &= \$2,846,222.20 \end{aligned}$$ Where: CFBT - Cash flow before tax FV - Face value YTM - Yield to maturity NOIB - Number of issued bonds

We can now input the above value along with the tax rate of 35% and calculate the aftertax cash flow: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Aftertax Cash Flow}_ \text{Coupon Bond}&= \$2,846,222.20 \times(1 - 35\%) \\[10pt] &= \$1,850,044.43 \end{aligned}$$

Let's recap what we have learned in this exercise! First, we explained the key term of the exercise - the zero-coupon bond. Then we calculated the number of bonds we were required to issue for our company to raise $53,000,000. Then we examined the repayment values at 20 years for both types of bonds. Finally, in the last step, we examined how the after-tax cash flows compare. Our research shows that companies might prefer the issuance of zero coupon bonds as the cash flow for the zeroes is a cash inflow for the company. The company can write off the interest expense for the year, which is considered a cash inflow.
